titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Carole Hyatt Papers
1947-2006 (bulk, 1980s-1990s)
MS 3105
titlestmt.author: Larry Weimer

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-25 10:02:40 -0400.

physdesc.extent: in 19 boxes + 1.09 terabytes of digitized audiotapes

did.abstract: The Carole Hyatt papers include transcripts, notes, audiotapes, working files, and publicity material related to the author and career consultant Carole Hyatt's publications, workshops, and other initiatives. These especially relate to her trilogy of books exploring the relationship of individuals to a changing workplace: "When Smart People Fail" (1987), "Shifting Gears" (1990), and "Lifetime Employability" (1995), as well as to the ramifications of women's expanding role in the workplace. The collection holds about 670 audiotapes, principally of Hyatt's interviews with individuals and focus groups, which underlie much of her published work. About 450 of these have been digitized for access.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized in four series:
Series I. Press, Publicity and Fan Letters, 1947-2006.
Series II. Research and Working Files, 1976-2005.
Series III. Audiotapes, 1975-2003, undated.
Series IV. Videotapes, circa 1980-2004, undated.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Author, entrepreneur, and career consultant Carole Hyatt (née Schwartz) was born in 1935 in New York City. Her early life was directed toward the theatre, earning a Bachelor of Science degree in Theatre and Education from Syracuse University in 1956 and her Master of Arts degree in Children's Theater and Creative Dramatics from the University of Denver in 1959. In the early 1960s, with a focus on children's programming, Hyatt worked as a producer in theatre and, at CBS, in television. In 1966 she married Gordon Hyatt, whom she met at CBS. The Hyatts have one child, daughter Ariel.

In 1966, Hyatt co-founded, with social analyst June Esserman, the research firm Hyatt/Esserman Research Associates, later know as Child Research Service. Along with analyst Daniel Yankelovich, Hyatt and Esserman provided research services to corporations and other organizations on women, youth and family interaction issues, supporting the creation of products, services and marketing strategies by their clients. This work led to the publication of Hyatt's first books, "The Woman's Selling Game: How to Sell Yourself — and Anything Else" (1979) and "Women and Work: Honest Answers to Real Questions" (1980).

In 1982, Esserman died of a heart attack. With the loss of her partner, Hyatt sold the firm in 1983 to McCollum Spielman, though remaining on the Board of Directors until 1986. While constrained by a non-compete agreement until 1986, Hyatt began work on a new book, which would be published as "When Smart People Fail: Rebuilding Yourself for Success" (1987). She interviewed 176 people for the book from various fields, both the well-known and the not well known, to explore the career setbacks of individuals and how they recovered from them. Through the 1980s and into the mid-1990s, Hyatt continued conducting interviews with men and women concerning their relationship with the workplace and with one another as society shifted to a broader acceptance of women in the professional workforce. Interviews about surviving corporate downsizing and other corporate upheavals, changing careers and finding an identity outside of the corporate setting, and finding fulfillment in retirement, among other topics, led to Hyatt's next books: "Shifting Gears: How to Master Career Change and Find the Work That's Right for You" (1992) and "Lifetime Employability: How to Become Indispensable" (1995).

Hyatt took the lessons documented in her books and used them to create workshops that she ran for organizations. These workshops were aimed at both individuals, often women, empowering them to take charge of their careers and lives, and at teams of people, unlocking the creative energies of organizations, a process referred to as "ideation." Her appeal spread internationally, perhaps especially to Asia, notably Japan, where she had a close partnership with Sakayori Noriko in the translation and publication of her work. In addition to workshops, Hyatt was a frequent speaker at conferences, such as those of the National Association for Executive Women (NAFE).

Continuing to find new partnerships and vehicles for building out her essential messages, among other initiatives, Hyatt created the Leadership Forum in the late 1990s for improving career strategies and leadership qualities for women and, in 2013, Mission: Getting to Next as a career transition program for women.
(The above note was based on various on-line sources, including Wikipedia, as well as on documents in the collection.)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers. The audio and videocassette tapes in the collection are restricted; see specifics at the series level below.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p:
Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to 20 exposures of stable, unbound material per day.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. Note especially that the audiotapes and videocassettes in the collection are protected by copyright, which N-YHS does not hold. Copies may not be made of these without permission of the copyright owner. Contact manuscripts@nyhistory.org for further information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the Carole Hyatt Papers, MS 3105, New-York Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Approximately 450 of the audiotapes in the collection were digitized in November 2016 by The Media Preserve for the New-York Historical Society. The paper portion of the collection was processed, and the overall collection described in a finding aid, in 2019-20 by archivist Larry Weimer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes transcripts, notes, audiotapes, working files, reference material, videotapes, and publicity material related to Carole Hyatt's publications and workshops. These especially relate to her trilogy of books exploring the relationship of individuals to a changing workplace: "When Smart People Fail" (1987), "Shifting Gears" (1990), and "Lifetime Employability" (1995). Also prominent in the working files are various concepts she researched for potential publication, such as the impact of women's increased earnings power on personal relationships and the attributes of successful couples. The range of Hyatt's activities are represented here, from books to workshops to corporate consulting to television programming possibilities. There is rich material on Hyatt's Japan initiatives of the 1980-1990s.

Hyatt's research files for her books of the 1980s and 1990s comprise a substantial portion of the collection. These include Hyatt's notes taken during her interviews and transcriptions of many of those interviews. The collection holds about 670 audiotapes, the bulk of which are of Hyatt interviews or recordings of her on radio interviews, making presentations, and the like. About 450 of these tapes have been digitized and can be listened to on-site at New-York Historical Society.

did.unittitle: Series I. Press, Publicity and Fan Letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes publicity material (brochures, advertisements, flyers, conference programs, tour schedules, etc.) for Carole Hyatt's books, speaking engagements, workshops, and other Hyatt appearances and initiatives; clippings, articles, tearsheets, and other documents from press outlets, including international sources, relating to Hyatt's books and appearances; and complimentary and appreciative "fan" letters sent to Hyatt.

The bulk of the series dates from the late 1970s and into the early 2000s. However, there are a small number of documents representing Hyatt's early life and career (then still known as Carole Schwartz, prior to her marriage).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The bulk of the series was originally in 3-ring binders compiled by the Hyatts. The series opens with that material, though it was removed from the binders during processing.

Following the unbound documents are similar publicity and press materials that were found by the processing archivist throughout the collection. A final folder includes documents from Hyatt/Schwartz's early life and career; the contents are noted at the folder level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Holds three programs from theatre productions at the All Saints Parish House in Bayside, Long Island, in which Hyatt (then Carole Schwartz) performed in her youth (1947-48); a "how-to" booklet from Woman's Day for producing a childen's play "The Emperor's New Clothes," with a script by Schwartz (1962); four publicity photographs of Hyatt; letterhead stationery from Schwartz/Hyatt's various initiatives (including the Peppermint Players, ChildWays, etc.); two articles regarding Schwartz's child-oriented work (1960s); a circa 1980s brochure for McCollum/Spielman Associates' Child Research Services (originally co-founded by Hyatt); and other documents.

did.unittitle: Series II. Research and Working Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes files with transcripts and notes from many of the interviews Carole Hyatt conducted in the 1980s and 1990s for her books, both those proposed and those realized, as well as for her many related initiatives. Some original audiotapes of the interviews are found here, filed with the transcripts (most audiotapes can be found in Series III).

The series also holds Hyatt's general working files with remarks delivered at workshops and other venues; project proposals for books, television shows, partnerships, etc.; releases for interviews; reference material; and other documents.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files comprising this series were pulled together by the processing archivist from a variety of files in the collection, some well-ordered, others less so. Consequently, while the content of individual files remain as found in their original form and any perceived original connections among files was also retained, the overall arrangement and categorization of the material was established by the processing archivist.
The series is organized in two subseries:
Subseries II.A. Interview Transcripts and Notes, 1985-2002
Subseries II.B. Working Files, 1976-2005

did.unittitle: Subseries II.A. Interview Transcripts and Notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes files of documents related to interviews conducted in the course of Hyatt's research for books published or for potential books and other initiatives. The files hold transcripts of the taped interviews or handwritten notes from the interview or both. Some files hold the cassette tape of the interview; those are noted in the container list. For the most, though, the related tapes were held apart from the document files and are found in Series III.

Especially well-represented in this subseries are transcripts related to two of Hyatt's books "When Smart People Fail" (1987) and "Shifting Gears" (1990). Related material in the subseries that did not explicitly lead to a book but are concerned with the workplace of the late twentieth century, men and women's relation to the workplace, and the shifting notions of personal success are interviews on the themes of "corporate survivors," acquiring wisdom, and handling success. The evolving role of women in society is considered in interviews on the topic of winning (i.e., successful) couples and the impact on women of gaining financial power as they enter the workforce.

A note on names: The form and spelling of names in the container list was taken from the documents. However, it is clear that variant forms and spellings of many of the names can be found in the overall collection, specifically between the transcripts and working documents (Series II) and the audiotape labels (Series III). The processing archivist noted some of these variant names, but surely not all, nor was any attempt made to reconcile them or determine a single "correct" name to use. Accordingly, users should keep in mind the potential for name variants and be cautious in relying exclusively on keyword searches.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The subseries is arranged by research topic, with the two major topics first (Smart/Fail and Shifting Gears), followed by other well-defined themes advancing chronologically. Miscellaneous or less well-defined themes follow, also then advancing chronologically. For the most part, the processing archivist was able to discern the theme of the interview based on explicit markings, file structures, etc. Question marks were used in the label in cases of uncertainty.

Archival folders were used to group thematic materials together and to sequence them in an accessible manner. However, the original folders were retained and the original contents were retained within those original folders. In part, this was done because the folders include notations. But it was also done for users to be able to perceive for themselves the visual clues potentially linking individual folders together thematically.

Whenever tapes were found in a folder with, or very commonly wrapped inside, its related transcript/notes, the tape and documents were kept together. Documents/tapes now held in paper slings (i.e., not in an original folder) were generally found loose in the collection with no folder. To the extent the archivist could be reasonably sure of the topic, the material was placed in a subject category. Otherwise, these were mostly placed at the end of the subseries as unidentified topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries includes Carole Hyatt's files concerning her various initiatives, both proposed and realized. The subseries includes the proposals for at least two of Hyatt's published books ("When Smart People Fail" and "Lifetime Employability"), along with book projects that did not come to fruition. There are interview logs and interview release forms and a few interview notes mixed into the files, but generally the interview transcripts and notes are found in subseries II.A.

Beyond Hyatt's books, the subseries holds files with Hyatt's remarks for workshops, panels, and the like; proposed partnerships with corporations and with other consultants; various notes and reference material informing her work; and two of Hyatt's reports from the mid-1970s during her years at her firm, Child Research Service. There is a rich set of files on her Japan-based initiatives, circa 1990, that she executed with Noriko Sakayori. And a set of files with proposals for television shows and segments, especially for a situation comedy (sitcom) to be named "Shirley."

Because the content varies considerably among the topics represented in the subseries,the container list provides more detail on content, including identifying where a few interview notes can be found.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The subseries is arranged by topic. The subseries opens with Hyatt's early Child Research Service reports and moves into files pertaining to her various book projects, advancing in rough chronological order. Following these book-oriented files are those concerning workshops and other initiatives, concluding with files of miscellaneous notes and reference material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes, among other documents, book proposal (1985) from Hyatt and Linda Gottlieb for "When Smart People Fail: How Defeat Can Lead to Success"; publication contract with Simon & Schuster (1985); contract with the book's German publisher (1987); examples of interview request letters; interview logs; interviewee releases; permissions for quotations from published works; summary of editorial comments from Patricia Soliman at Simon & Schuster; a letter from China observing the relevance of the book to that country at that time (1988?) and offering to write a Chinese translation. Two transcripts with the logs: Bert Salzman and Richard Melluzzo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes, among other documents, interviewee releases and logs; proposals, concepts, outlines, brief introduction for book "When Smart People Become Wise: A New Psychology of Life Choices" (or alternative sub-title: The Art of Problem Finding); draft questionnaires; letters from potential assistants; reference material; and notes. The file has a copy of the "When Smart People Fail" proposal that includes the first page (missing in an earlier file's copy).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes three files with, among other documents, a proposal for book "The Job Game After 40", a proposal for a book engaging with retirement, and a proposal for American Express for a workshop "Shifting Gears for the 401k Retiree Market"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes outlines of remarks and other documents related to Hyatt's presentations to women's groups, corporate sessions, and others on risktaking, backlash against women, ideation/creativity, leadership, etc., especially as these relate to women, though not necessarily so. One extensive file is "Women and Risk Taking: Expanding Your Comfort Level" presented to Digital Equipment Corp's Women's Conclave (1992); intermixed in that file are documents related to Hyatt's presentation "The New 'Work Family' for Survival in the Year 2000" at the 1992 Woman Inc trade fair in Jamaica.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Hyatt's extensive correspondence with Noriko Sakayori in Japan and other documents concerning their collaboration on seminars, speeches, and other Hyatt initiatives and business proposals in Japan. Topics primarily included a "woman's natural ability for business" and mentoring/networking.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes various files on possible and actual partnerships with organizations and initiatives. Among these is a creative workshop, named ThoughtStorm, in a collaboration with consultant Ruth Zanes and the cartoonist Mort Gerberg, and a series of Head of State documentaries aimed at the tourism industry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes extensive files on a proposed sitcom "Shirley," with the feature character a woman starting a new life after the death of her husband. Also files on a quiz show "The Family Game," "Chances Are" short segments for Mary Tyler Moore's show "Today's Woman," "Focus Group" for daytime TV, and others.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous Lists and Notes about Tapes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes lists of some of the Hyatt tapes. These lists provide some context for some of the audiotapes in Series III, and were used by the processing archivist as a source for some of the notes in the Series III description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes approximately 670 audiocassette tapes, 457 of which have been digitized for access. None of the tapes were listened to during processing but the overall subject content is clear from the tape labels and overall collection context. The bulk of the tapes are of interviews that Carole Hyatt conducted in the 1980s and 1990s during her research for her books, both those realized and those contemplated but not realized or realized in a different form than originally planned. Most of these interviews were with individuals, but also included focus groups of men and/or women, couples, business partners, or other combinations. The bulk, reflecting the experiences of regular people, are with relatively unknown individuals, but some notable figures appear, such as newscaster Walter Cronkite, author William Shirer, boxer Gerry Cooney, former U.S. senator George McGovern, Vice-Presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro, entrepreneur and founder of Famous Amos cookies Wally Amos, Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak, and New York University president and former Congressman John Brademas.

Generally, the tapes are well-labeled as to the name of the interviewee, but often lack a date or identification as to which project they pertain to. Indexes found in Series II (folder title "Miscellaneous Lists and Notes about Tapes," Box 9, folder 20) can provide guidance as to the context of some of the tapes and were used by the processing archivist in developing notes in the container list.

The tapes also include recordings of Hyatt appearances on radio and television talk shows, remarks at presentations and conferences, and, judging from the labels, her dictation of book outlines and chapters (possibly "Shifting Gears" specifically). Other tapes include recordings made by Hyatt of talks given by others on topics of interest, as well as commercially produced tapes on time management, motivational techniques, and other topics of use to Hyatt in her research.

In 2016, 457 of the audiotapes were digitized for accessibility and use. These were chosen more or less randomly so there is no overall difference between the content of the digitized and non-digitized tapes. Different access restrictions apply to both and are further described at the subseries level.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized in two subseries:
Subseries III.A. Audiotapes, Digitized
Subseries III.B. Audiotapes, Not Digitized
Access restrictions apply to both subseries and these are further described at the subseries level.

physdesc.extent: (457 cassette tapes in 6 boxes; 1.09 terabytes of digital files)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes 457 audiotapes in the collection that have been digitized and are available to be listened to on-site at New-York Historical Society. In digital form, these amounted to 914 digital files totaling 1.09 terabytes. The container list identifies all digitized audiotapes, with information taken from the labels on the tapes (that is, no tapes were listened to to determine content).

The title used in the container list is the interviewee name or other core identifying information as found on the tape label and as used to name the related digital files. Generally each tape includes only one interviewee but where multiple names appear, those are included also in the title. Variant forms and spellings of names were common, both from side to side of a tape and among multiple tapes used for an interviewee. Variants were also found between the tapes and related paper documents in the collection. The processing archivist noted some of these variant names, especially where it seemed they might impede discovery. But surely not all variants were noted, nor was any attempt made to reconcile them or determine a single "correct" name to use. Accordingly, users should keep in mind the potential for name variants and be cautious in relying exclusively on keyword searches.

Because it is expected that patrons will only have access to the digital files, not to the physical tapes themselves, all additional information found on the label was transcribed into a note at the file level; these transcriptions are identified in the note within "quotation marks." Information not in quotation marks was supplied by the archivist in an effort to help patrons navigate the material, especially in terms of relating the digital files they will be using to the original tape.

All the tapes are represented in digital form by two files, one for side A and one for side B. This is emphasized in the container list title with the reference to "1 tape/2 files." Some interviews required two or more tapes; when this was clearly identifiable during processing it was noted in the title by such references as "2 tapes/4 files." When the possible connection between tapes was uncertain, the potential connection is referred to in a note at the tape level.

Both sides of all tapes were digitized without regard to, or even knowledge of, whether the second side had content. Accordingly, the second digital file associated with a tape may be, and likely often will be, blank. It is unknown if Hyatt did this consistently, but the labels on the tapes are commonly noted as to whether the second side (Side B) had content and to what extent (e.g., 1/8, full side, etc.). The use of multiple tapes is often indicated by labels referencing side 3, side 4, etc. The presence of such leading indicators was noted by the archivist in the container list. On the other hand, many tapes are labeled on one side only, with nothing noted on Side B. It seems likely that these were indicators that Side B was blank. However, the archivist did not want to imply this, as it might not be the case, and so no reference is made in the notes to the absence of a label on Side B.

Very few of the tapes were labeled to indicate which book or project they related to. However, indexes in the paper files provide this information for some of the tapes. These indexes are found in Series II (folder title "Miscellaneous Lists and Notes about Tapes," Box 9, folder 20). These indexes were used as the source for some of the notes added to the container list by the processing archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Approximately one-half of the digitized tapes had dates on their labels. These tapes are presented first in the container list, in chronological order. These are followed by the other tapes, which are undated. Undated tapes are arranged in alphabetical order by interviewee surname, group name, or other key identifier from the label. Some undated tapes could be associated with a dated tape and so were included at that point in the container list.

The physical audiotapes are arranged differently from the container list. These are boxed in the order in which they were digitized, with each tape assigned a sequence number. The sequence number/order of digitization was random with no relationship to chronology, subject matter, etc.

The digital files are maintained by the Digital Collections staff. The file names include a combination of the sequence number, an "a" or "b" indicating the side of the tape, and the interviewee or other content identifier from the tape label. For content spanning two or more tapes, each with its unique sequence number, a "c," "d," etc. is used with the name to associate the files.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: There are conditions governing access to the audiotapes and to the digital files of those tapes. For further information about these conditions, patrons must contact the manuscripts curator at manuscripts@nyhistory.org in advance of their visit.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The digital files in this subseries were created in November 2016 by The Media Preserve for the New-York Historical Society. In February 2020 archivist Larry Weimer expanded on the inventory of these files to include further details from the labels of the tapes themselves. These details were then used to create the container list for this subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries holds 214 audiocassette tapes that have not been digitized. These are a mix of interviews conducted by Carole Hyatt, radio interviews, presentations by Hyatt, and some commercial products by other speakers. (The tapes were not listened to during processing; this description is based on the labels on the tapes.) The container list provides some additional detail on the individual tapes in the subseries.

In addition to the audiotapes in this subseries, there are about 42 audiotapes that were found with transcripts, notes and other paper documents in Hyatt's files. These were left in place and can be found in Series II.A Interview Transcripts and Notes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The tapes in this subseries are grouped by the original containers they were found in by the processing archvist in 2020. These containers were shoeboxes and other such containers, some with labeling that suggested, at least for some, the overall content. Some tapes were loose in the collection, that is, no longer in a container. Several of the containers were fairly empty and it is possible that tapes were removed from them for digitization. The tapes are boxed in smaller containers labeled A-D within two larger record cartons.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The audiotapes are restricted because of their fragility and because N-YHS has no equipment on which to play them. Please contact the curator of manuscripts at manuscripts@nyhistory.org for further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
32 tapes found together, but loose in the collection. Among these are:
DATED TAPES: A Conversation with Joyce Hauser: "Women and Work" (1980); Hyatt Job Clinic: "Women and Work" with Joan Hamburg (1980); 2 St. Louis radio interviews (1980); Hyatt/Avon (1983); YMCA Strategic Marketing Workshop (1983); "only child" (1983); Hyatt Associates panel group (1983); "raising daughters; Mothers/daughters" (1984); Shirley and/or Trish Ballard (1985); executive wives seminar (1985); "St. Vincent's" (1987); radio interview (1990); Japan-related (1993-94); Leslie Smith/NAFE/trigger (1994).
UNDATED: Jean Avery; two unnamed groups; 3 of 4 (one tape missing) re: WSG marketing workshop; "Hyatt"; one unlabeled.
COMMERCIAL PRODUCTS or OTHER SPEAKERS: 6 sided "Today's Saleswoman" (1982) and tapes by Jack Boland, Zig Zigler, Alan Cimberg, Barbara Tuchman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 15 tapes found in box labeled "Smart People Radio." These are: "attitude and goal-setting" (1981); 3 radio shows in 1987; 2 radio shows in 1988; Seattle radio show (undated); two undated tapes from WNYC in New York; undated "breakfast with Bob and Betty" with Hyatt and Linda Gottlieb; three tapes from the National Association for Female Executives (NAFE) first national seminar convention, two of which feature Hyatt speaking on "The Selling Game" and "Strategic Marketing Workshop"; a Hyatt presentation tape "How to Sell Yourself and Everything Else"; and one commercial product by Shakti Gawain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 18 tapes found in a container labeled "corporate survivors." Holds (1990): Bill Semanie, Maureen Ferguson; (1991): Lee Ann Suriner, Denise Higgins, John Ruehl, Larry Finkelstein, Bob Goddell, Deena Hadley(?), Tom Drucker, and others unidentified; (undated): Cliff Lenz, Dino DeConcini, Jack Pfister, Barbara Davidson, Judith Steinberg, Bob Singerman, and a few others; one unlabeled.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 43 tapes found in container labeled "typed interview tapes." A few are dated 1991; most are undated but seem likely to be from about the same year. Surnames include, among others, Nordstrom, Mazer, Maitlen (1991), Mantyla, McCann, Detroit focus group (1991), Reilly, Roman, Schoenfeld (1991), Freeman, Dallas women focus group, Feld, Strode (1991), San Francisco focus group, Whalen, Tunick, Yavitz (1991), Sedlar, Atlanta focus group (1991), Ashwood, Blanke, Brockner, Horton, Nast, Melanson, Moore Jr., Jones, Perkins, Erkut, Daniel, Francy, Kravitz, Koz, Brown, Cavanaugh, Bride (1991), Aden (1991), Ragovia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 19 tapes found in an unlabeled box but that appear to relate to research on the ramifications of women having financial earning power. Surnames include: (1995) McKearnan, Berger, 50+ New York women's group; (1996) Dubrow; (1997) Kahn, Firestone, McCoy, New York/Big Apple women's single group, Iredale, Mancusi, "Bk club gp," Durso, "DC and CH book discussion," "Carole and Deborah"; (undated) Hyde. Also tapes labeled "dictation" (1995) and "Carole" (1997).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 11 tapes found in box with the label "Wisdom Tapes" in two places, though struckthrough in one of those instances. A set of 8 tapes in the box were banded together; names on those tapes were: Michael Miller, Joe deCola, Doc Severinsen, Focus Group, Bruno Challamel, Eschwan Winding, Terra Mizwa, and one unlabeled. Other tapes in this box were Michael Melia and Men's Architecture Group (2).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 9 tapes found in a container without a label, but small documents, kept with the tapes, indicate these related to Hyatt's research for the "money book." Names include: Dallas focus group (1991), Jean Elliott (1997), "background, money book, Carole and Deborah," (1997), London forum and interviews (3 tapes, 1998), Joanne Mast (1998), and two unlabeled.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Holds 41 of 67 tapes found in a box labeled "Biz Book." Includes surnames: Loren (1999), Lehmann (1999), Jannovitz (1994), Gilligan (1999), D'Agnato, Ward, Bisquat, Goodstein (1994), Montoya (1995), Hubers (1999), Rowell (1999), Kipper (1997), various on tape (2003), University of Illinois (1992), dictation (1994), "When Smart People Fail" (2 copies, 1988) by Carole Hyatt distributed by Church of Today, "The Selling Game" talk by Carole Hyatt distributed by NAFE, "Creating a Buying Atmosphere: Presenting, Probing, Blending" by Carole Hyatt (Transdesign Conf., 3 copies), "Setting Goals: The Playing Piece, Building Affinity and Listening Skills" by Hyatt (NAFE Conf, 3 copies); conference intro (1990), "Shifting Gears" by Hyatt at the International Conference on Outplacement (2 copies), Hyatt on WOR radio (1996), Hair Club for Men, Hamburg (1990), "Shifting Gears" (1991) by Hyatt distributed by Church of Today, Roy (1988, microcassette), and Jack Boland on "The 34th AA Anniversary." Also an envelope of 6 tapes related to "when she earns more" (1997).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Holds 26 of 67 tapes found in a box labeled "Biz Book." Includes "Shifting Gears: Creating Possibilities for Career Change" by Carole Hyatt, presented by Crain's Business Detroit and Strategies (two copies of the packet, each with two tapes, 1992). Includes a set of 5 tapes re: "Shifting Gears", Warwick Hotel (1990). Other names: WLNA radio "Women's Change" (1997), Jim Cracchiolo (1999), Louise Hay, "The Women's Selling Game: Creating a Buying Atmosphere: Presenting, Probing, Blending" by Hyatt (Transdesigns Conference), Pete/WJM (1984), Warsaw discussion (1990), Budapest group, "How to be on Top of the World" by Yyatt (1991), Hair Thinning (1990). Also various commercial products: "Painless Prospecting" by Denise Roberts (2 copies, 1991), Joseph Mancusi "Why Some People and Organizations Will Never Succeed," "Jampolsky/Howe "Healing Relationships" (1984), Jean Houston "Life: The Art of the Possible" (1983), Stephanie Beling "Success with Weight Control" (1989), Jacquelyn Reinach music tape for UN International Year of the Family (1993), and Tim Wheater music tape (1986).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes 40 videocassette tapes. All but one are VHS format; the exception is a U-Matic, noted in the container list. None of the tapes were viewed during processing so the overall content was only discerned from the labels. Generally, the tapes appear to be recordings of Carole Hyatt's appearances on television talk shows and in other venues, publicity spots and other publicity material, demonstration tapes for workshops, and some presentations.
All tapes in the series are listed individually below. Quotation marks are used in the container list to indicate wording transcribed from the label(s) on the tape.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in chronological order, with undated videocassettes at the end.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The videotapes are restricted because of their fragility and because N-YHS has no equipment on which to play them. Please contact the curator of manuscripts at manuscripts@nyhistory.org for further information.
